facts.text: Appeal from a judgment and decree of the Judicial Commissioner of Coorg dated 1st April, 1946, in Original Suit No. 1 of 1945.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Appeal from a judgment and decree of the Judicial Commissioner of Coorg dated 1st April, 1946, in Original Suit No, 1 of 1945.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on February 9, 1951 by FAZL ALI J.

anchor.surface_text: 1951. February 9. The judgment of the Court was deliv- ered by FAZL ALI J.--This is an appeal from a judgment of the Judicial Commissioner of Coorg in a suit filed by the first respondent  hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff  against the appellant  hereinafter referred to as the first defendant  and the second respondent  hereinafter referred to as the second defendant , for the specific performance of a companytract.

facts.text: Suit filed by the first respondent (plaintiff) against the appellant (first defendant) and the second respondent (second defendant) for specific performance of a contract.

anchor.surface_text: ered by FAZL ALI J.--This is an appeal from a judgment of the Judicial Commissioner of Coorg in a suit filed by the first respondent  hereinafter referred to as the plaintiff  against the appellant  hereinafter referred to as the first defendant  and the second respondent  hereinafter referred to as the second defendant , for the specific performance of a companytract.

facts.text: First defendant owned a bungalow in Mercara known as Morvern Lodge.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant owned a bungalow in Mercara known as Morvern Lodge . The suit which has given rise to this appeal was instituted by the plaintiff for the specific performance of an alleged companytract of sale in respect of this bungalow.

facts.text: First defendant owned certain estates in Mercara.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the first defendant owned certain es- tates in Mercara, and one Mr. White was an alternative director in one of the estates, and Youngman was the manager of another estate also belonging to the first defendant and was looking after Morvern Lodge during his absence.

facts.text: Mr. White was an alternate director in one of the estates owned by first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the first defendant owned certain es- tates in Mercara, and one Mr. White was an alternative director in one of the estates, and Youngman was the manager of another estate also belonging to the first defendant and was looking after Morvern Lodge during his absence.

facts.text: Youngman was the manager of another estate belonging to the first defendant and was looking after Morvern Lodge during his absence.

anchor.surface_text: tates in Mercara, and one Mr. White was an alternative director in one of the estates, and Youngman was the manager of another estate also belonging to the first defendant and was looking after Morvern Lodge during his absence.

facts.text: About the middle of 1944, the plaintiff asked White if he would cable to the first defendant his offer of Rs. 4,000 for the bungalow.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that about the middle of 1944, the plaintiff asked White if he would cable to the first defendant his offer of Rs. 4,000 for the bungalow, and, on the 1st June, 1944, White sent a cable to the first defendant to the following effect -- Have enquiries Mercara bungalow if for sale, wire lowest figure.

facts.text: On 1st June 1944, White sent a cable to first defendant: Have enquiries Mercara bungalow if for sale, wire lowest figure.

anchor.surface_text: the plaintiff asked White if he would cable to the first defendant his offer of Rs. 4,000 for the bungalow, and, on the 1st June, 1944, White sent a cable to the first defendant to the following effect -- Have enquiries Mercara bungalow if for sale, wire lowest figure.

facts.text: On 24th July 1944, plaintiff wrote to first defendant offering Rs. 5,000 for the bungalow.

anchor.surface_text: On the 24th July, 1944, the plaintiff wrote to the first defendant that he was prepared to purchase the bungalow for Rs. 5,000 and if the offer was acceptable to him, he  the first defendant  should inform the plaintiff to which bank he should issue a cheque in payment of the price.

facts.text: Youngman sent a cable to first defendant: Have had offer Morvern Lodge rupees six thousand for immediate possession.

anchor.surface_text: This letter was followed up by a cable from Youngman to the first defendant to the following effect -- Have had offer Morvern Lodge rupees six thousand for immediate possession.

facts.text: On 8th August 1944, Youngman received cable from first defendant: Wont accept less than rupees ten thousand.

anchor.surface_text: On the 8th August, 1944, Youngman received a cable from the first defendant saying Wont accept less than rupees ten thousand.

facts.text: On 7th August 1944, plaintiff wrote to Youngman asking whether his offer had been accepted and saying prepared to accept higher price if reasonable.

anchor.surface_text: On the 7th August, 1944, the plaintiff wrote to Youngman asking him whether his offer had been accepted, and saying that he was prepared to accept any higher price if found reasonable.

facts.text: On 8th August 1944, first defendant sent airgraph to Youngman explaining cables from Youngman and White.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, on the 8th August, the first defendant sent an airgraph to Youngman, which states inter alia -- I got a cable from you a few days ago saying you had had an offer of Rs. 6,000 for Morvern Lodge.

facts.text: On 9th August 1944, Youngman wrote to plaintiff quoting the cable: Wont accept less than rupees ten thousand.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th August, 1944, Youngman wrote to the plaintiff as follows - In reply to your letter, dated 7th August, I received yesterday a cable from Co1. MacPherson regarding your offer of Rs. 6,000, which reads as follows -- Wont accept less than rupees ten thousand MacPherson.

facts.text: Plaintiff stated in plaint that Youngman's letter received on 14th August 1944 and immediately accepted counter-offer in writing.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff has stated in his plaint that this letter of Youngman was received by him on the 14th August, 1944, and he immediately accepted the companynter-offer made by the first defendant , and companyfirmed it in writing in a letter addressed to Youngman.

facts.text: In evidence, plaintiff stated he met Youngman on 11th August 1944 after receiving letter, told him personally would pay Rs. 10,000.

anchor.surface_text: In his evidence, however, the plain- tiff has stated that he met Youngman on the 11th August after receiving his letter and told him personally that he would pay Rs. 10,000 for the bungalow and will require immediate delivery.

facts.text: Plaintiff agreed to bear conveyance charges.

anchor.surface_text: There was also some talk about the companyveyance charges, and ultimately the plaintiff agreed to bear those charges.

facts.text: On 14th August 1944, plaintiff wrote to Youngman confirming oral offer of ten thousand for the bungalow.

anchor.surface_text: Afterwards, he wrote to Youngman a letter on the 14th August in which after referring to the companyversation he had with the latter he stated as follows -- I hereby companyfirm my oral offer of ten thousand for the bungalow.

facts.text: On 17th August 1944, Subbayya wrote to Youngman confirming offer of Rs. 10,500 made previous day.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that three days later, i.e. on the 17th August, one Subbayya wrote to Youngman stating that he companyfirmed his offer of Rs. 10,500 made to him  Youngman  the previous day for the purchase of the bungalow

facts.text: Youngman did not communicate Subbayya's offer to first defendant.

anchor.surface_text: It seems that Youngman did number companymunicate Subbayyas offer to the first defendant, but sent a cable to him on the 26th August

facts.text: On 26th August 1944, Youngman cabled first defendant: Offered ten thousand Morvern Lodge immediate possession. May I sell.

anchor.surface_text: but sent a cable to him on the 26th August to the following effect -- Offered ten thousand Morvern Lodge immediate posses- sion. May I sell.

facts.text: On 26th August 1944, White cabled first defendant: Hold offer for Morvern Bungalow rupees eleven thousand cash subject immediately acceptance and occupation.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, White cabled to the first defendant in the following terms- Hold offer for Morvern Bungalow rupees eleven thousand cash subject immediately acceptance and occupation. Strongly recommend acceptance.

facts.text: Second defendant paid Rs. 11,000 and occupied the bungalow.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the second defendant paid the amount of Rs. 11,000 and occupied the bungalow.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner of Coorg held there was a concluded contract but awarded Rs. 3,000 compensation instead of specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner of Coorg who tried the suit held that there was a companycluded companytract, but, instead of giving to the plain- tiff a decree for specific performance, awarded a sum of Rs. 3,000 as companypensation to him.

facts.text: First defendant appealed after obtaining certificate under section 109(c) CPC; plaintiff did not appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decree, the first defendant alone has appealed, after obtaining a cer- tificate under section 109  c  of the Civil Procedure Code from the Judicial Commissioner. The plaintiff has number pre- ferred any appeal.

facts.text: Court held there was no concluded contract on 14th August 1944.

anchor.surface_text: We however find it difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any companycluded company- tract on the 14th August, 1944

facts.text: Plaintiff's case: cable of 8th August was counter-offer accepted by him, completing contract.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that the cable sent by the first defendant on the 5th August, and received by Youngman on the 8th, to the effect that he would number accept less than Rs. 10,000, was a companynter-offer made by him through Youngman to the plaintiff, and the companytract was companyplete as soon as he accepted it.

facts.text: Youngman stated in evidence he felt improper to entertain Subbayya's higher offer and did not communicate it.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, Youngman has frankly stated in his evidence that he felt it improper to entertain Subbayyas higher offer and did number companymunicate it to the first defendant.
for the specific performance of a contract.

issues.text: The question to be decided in this case is whether in view of the correspondence which has been reproduced, it could be held that there was a concluded contract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff on the 14th August, as stated by him in the plaint.

anchor.surface_text: The question to be decided in this case is whether in view of the companyrespondence which has been reproduced, it companyld be held that there was a companycluded companytract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff on the 14th August, as state

issues.text: The real question is whether the first defendant had made a counter-offer in his cable of the 5th August or he was merely inviting offers.

anchor.surface_text: The real question is whether the first defendant had made a companynter-offer in his cable of the 5th August or he was merely inviting offers. The plaintiff in his letter of the 14th August addressed to Youngman, stated that he companyfirmed his oral offer of

arguments.claim: There was a concluded contract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: it could be held that there was a concluded contract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff

arguments.court_reasoning: Difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any concluded contract on the 14th August, 1944.

arguments.claim: Instead of specific performance, Rs. 3,000 compensation should be awarded.

anchor.surface_text: held that there was a concluded contract, but, instead of giving to the plain- tiff a decree for specific performance, awarded a sum of Rs. 3,000 as compensation

arguments.claim: The cable sent by the first defendant on the 5th August (received 8th) stating 'Wont accept less than Rs. 10,000' was a counter-offer made through Youngman to the plaintiff, and the contract was complete upon acceptance.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs case is that the cable sent by the first defendant on the 5th August, and received by Youngman on the 8th, to the effect that he would not accept less than Rs. 10,000, was a counter-offer made by him through Youngman to the plaintiff, and the contract was complete as soon as he accepted it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: efendant in the following terms- Hold offer for Morvern Bungalow rupees eleven thousand cash subject immediately acceptance and occupation. Strongly r

arguments.court_reasoning: No concluded contract on facts, supported by Harvey v. Facey.

arguments.claim: There was no concluded contract on the 14th August 1944.

anchor.surface_text: We however find it difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any concluded contract on the 14th August, 1944

arguments.claim: The first defendant's cable is analogous to Harvey v. Facey, where stating lowest price is not an offer.

anchor.surface_text: and we are supported in this view by the well-known case of Harvey v. Facey 1 , in which the facts were somewhat similar to those of the present case. In that case, the appellants had telegraphed to the respondents Will you sell us B.H.P.? Telegraph lowest cash price

arguments.claim: Mere statement of lowest price contains no implied contract to sell at that price.

anchor.surface_text: Their Lordships are of opinion that the mere statement of the lowest price at which the vendor would sell contains no implied contract to sell

arguments.claim: The correspondence shows parties did not treat the cable as a counter-offer: plaintiff confirmed 'my oral offer'; Youngman cabled 'Offered ten thousand... May I sell?'.

anchor.surface_text: The real question is whether the first defendant had made a counter-offer in his cable of the 5th August or he was merely inviting offers. The plaintiff in his letter of the 14th August addressed to Youngman, stated that he confirmed his oral offer of ten thousand for the bungalow, and he did not say in so many words that he ac- cepted the counter-offer of the first defendant.

arguments.claim: By 26th August 1944, Youngman was under influence of rival bidder/White and deliberately framed cable to prejudice plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Jindra Lal, counsel for the plaintiff, who pressed his points with force and ability, contended that by the 26th August, 1944, Youngman had come under the influence of the rival bidder or at least that of White who was support- ing him, and the cable to the first defendant was deliberately framed by Youngman, in such a way as to prejudice the plaintiff.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: last telegram. It has been companytended for the appellants that L.M. Faceys telegram should be read as saying yes to the first question put in the a

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing in the evidence to support such an extreme conclusion; Youngman frankly stated he felt improper to entertain higher offer and leaned towards plaintiff.

arguments.claim: Youngman felt improper to entertain Subbayya's higher offer and did not communicate it, favoring plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, Youngman has frankly stated in his evidence that he felt it improper to entertain Subbayyas higher offer and did not communicate it to the first defendant. This statement is supported by the cable of the 26th August

holdings.text: There was no concluded contract for the sale of Morvern Lodge in favour of the plaintiff on the 14th August, 1944

anchor.surface_text: difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any concluded contract on the 14th August, 1944

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entire correspondence and facts do not show concluded contract; cable stating minimum price not offer; analogy to Harvey v. Facey; parties' conduct treats it as invitation to offer

holdings.text: The first defendant's cable of the 5th August was not a counter-offer but merely invited offers

anchor.surface_text: The real question is whether the first defendant had made a counter-offer in his cable of the 5th August or he was merely inviting offers. The plaintiff in his letter of the 14th August addressed to Youngman, stated that he confirmed his oral offer of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plaintiff's letter confirms 'my oral offer' not acceptance of counter-offer; Youngman's cable seeks permission 'May I sell'; no party treated cable as counter-offer; proceeded as plaintiff's offer awaiting acceptance

holdings.text: Mere statement of lowest price contains no implied contract to sell at that price

anchor.surface_text: Their Lordships are of opinion that the mere statement of the lowest price at which the vendor would sell contains no implied contract to sell

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Harvey v. Facey principle to facts: defendant's cable analogous to price quotation not constituting offer capable of acceptance

holdings.text: No evidence supports contention that Youngman deliberately framed cable to prejudice plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: There is however nothing in the evidence to support such an extreme conclusion. On the other hand, Youngman has frankly stated in his evidence that he felt it improper to entertain Subbayyas higher offer

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel's contention rejected; Youngman's frank evidence credible and supported by cable; he favored plaintiff by not communicating higher offer

anchor.surface_text: by the well-known case of Harvey v. Facey 1 , in which the facts were somewhat similar to those of the present case. In that case, the appellants had telegraphed to the respondents Will you sell us B.H.P.? Telegraph lowest cash price , and the respondents had telegraphed in reply, Lowest price for B.H.P. pound 900,

precedents.cited_proposition: A telegram stating the lowest price in response to an inquiry for the lowest cash price does not constitute an offer to sell; it is merely information as to price, and an acceptance of that price does not form a binding contract without further acceptance by the vendor.
precedents.cited_holding: Their Lordships are of opinion that the mere statement of the lowest price at which the vendor would sell contains no implied contract to sell at that price to the persons making the inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: We however find it difficult to hold on the entire facts of the case that there was any concluded companytract on the 14th August, 1944, and we are supported in this view by the well-known case of Harvey v. Facey 1 , in which the facts were somewhat similar to those of the present case.

outcome.relief_summary: No concluded contract between the parties; lower court decree awarding compensation reversed
